report_title: Heavy Engineering Construction in the US
executive_summary: Heavy engineering contractors complete projects such as constructing oceanic navigational channels, beach dredging, mass transit support construction, tunnels, hydroelectric power plants and conservation development. Most of these projects are carried out by state and local governments independently or in conjunction with the federal government, so industry revenue tracks most closely with movements in public funding. Over the past five years, heavy engineering construction revenue has expanded at a CAGR of 1.1% to reach $34.4 billion in 2024, when revenue is set to grow 0.1%. Industry revenue has exhibited conflicting trends due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with nonresidential construction suffering mightily. As commodities prices, particularly crude oil, have been highly volatile, private investment in heavy engineering projects has been uneven. However, public funding for infrastructure projects has remained relatively stable, buoying industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Public Funding Drives Heavy Engineering Construction Spending
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Heavy engineering construction is largely reliant on public funding, accounting for over two-thirds of industry revenue in 2024. This helps to insulate the industry from some economic shocks that impact most private industries, like the COVID-19 pandemic, but it also leaves it particularly exposed to political headwinds.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Investments Have Faced Constraints in Recent Years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted investment in construction activity, with the value of private nonresidential construction falling consistently from 2020 through 2022. The initial outbreak of the pandemic broadly disrupted business activity, while lasting impacts like the popularity of working from home and general uncertainty kept the value of private nonresidential construction on the decline.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Input Costs and Supply Chain Issues Have Had an Impact
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, contractors have faced volatile materials costs; for example, the price of oil plummeted amid the COVID-19 pandemic then spiked in 2021 and 2022 amid supply chain issues and the war in Ukraine.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising wages have furthered pressured industry profitability
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wages have increased as more federally funded projects have become available, leading to companies demanding workers with specialist skills.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Environmental Concerns Boost Demand for Mass Transit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: According to the American Public Transport Association (APTA), overall rail-based ridership has increased over the past five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Construction Activity Will Build Up as the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Rolls Out
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The current Biden administration's deep commitment to funding infrastructure improvements will ensure that demand from federal projects supports heavy engineering enterprises in the immediate future.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Private Sector Demand Will Aid Heavy Engineering Construction Performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Aggregate private investment, which measures total spending by individuals and businesses on physical structures, equipment and software, is projected to grow. As it relates to the industry directly, such investment will likely manifest in those segments already awash with private capital, such as railroads.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Trade Volume Increases as Supply Chain Disruptions Have Dissipated
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Downstream freight services will grow in importance as rail freight accounts for a growing share of overall freight activity. This will enable heavy engineering contractors to capitalize on a surplus of new demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: NORMALIZING INPUT PRICES WILL ENABLE PROFIT GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Profit has been increasingly pressured by soaring oil and gas prices as a byproduct of supply chain disruptions related to the pandemic and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. Oil and gas prices have regressed from near-record highs offering relief for heavy engineering enterprises.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry are primarily engaged in heavy and engineering construction projects, with the exception of highway, street, bridge and airport construction. Work performed includes new work, reconstruction, rehabilitation and repairs. The industry also includes specialty trade contractors, if they are primarily active in activities related to engineering construction projects. Construction projects include waterworks, marine facilities development and open space improvement.

positive_impact_factors: High - Steady Barriers to Entry Level

key_trends: Large companies with adequate resources often secure government contracts and grants, sidelining smaller competitors. These larger engineering firms typically hire subcontractors to support regional and varied project needs, maintaining efficiency and broadening their reach.

Large-scale construction companies are typically selected to submit tenders on private-sector construction projects from a short list of preferred contractors, with reputation tied to quality of work. These companies will expand market share by establishing a presence across many geographic markets, often through acquisition.

Public funding is vital for heavy engineering construction. With over two-thirds of industry revenue in 2024 coming from public sources, heavy engineering projects are somewhat shielded from economic ups and downs, unlike private industries.

Environmental awareness is boosting mass transit demand. Due to environmental concerns and traffic congestion, more people and governments are opting for rail-based transportation, leading to new transit projects that benefit the heavy engineering sector.

Supply chain disruptions as a byproduct of the COVID-19 pandemic and ongoing conflict in Ukraine have thrust a wrench into business activity for many heavy engineering companies. This dynamic has limited revenue growth and has been worsened by high input prices for steel and oil, pressuring profit.

The Biden administration's Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act continues a trend of government investment in heavy engineering construction. The Inflation Reduction Act will also benefit industry contractors.

Heavy engineering contractors face heavy regulation. Projects like railroads, ports or tunnels are major pieces of infrastructure that must meet strict standards. This raises the barriers to entry to the industry.

The bloating of key input prices has profit gains for heavy engineering construction companies. Surges in both the price of steel and oil raised industry costs. Costs have more recently begun to fall.

The demand for employees with more technical skill suitable for specialized work has put upward pressure on wages. Wage costs have increased, forcing many enterprises to turn to more affordable subcontracted labor.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Amid a general pullback in private nonresidential construction, private investment in the industry declined as a byproduct of the pandemic roiling end markets and slashing future expectations.

Government agencies use heavy engineering construction services for power plant design and construction, waterway development, railroad and mass transit construction and land conservation services. States with prominent ports such as California and Texas will demand port construction and maintenance, while others will rely more on mass transit construction.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Federal spending for transportation is part of the federal government's discretionary spending budget. Outlays for transportation are used to service interstate transportation, like navigable waterways, interstate passenger rail and highways. When industry-relevant projects receive federal funding, industry revenue rises.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is the most populated in the United States, which has resulted in increased demand for heavy engineering services. The concentration of activity in this region reflects its high level of energy and heavy engineering construction, as well as rapidly growing populations in states like Florida. Marine construction and port and harbor operations also tend to concentrate in the Southeast due to their proximity to crucial trade routes. Demand for harbor and port construction has flourished as globalization needs expand.

Much of the heavy engineering activities in the Great Lakes involve maintenance and addition activities for the local industries that manufacture steel, petrochemicals and building materials. More than a quarter of the industry's regional activity is concentrated in Ohio, a hub for the growing natural gas industry. The heavy engineering construction industry is chiefly dependent on utilities construction for work.

California is a leader in power generation, particularly in solar and wind energy development, making it a likely destination for heavy engineering construction. The state is also home to a plethora of ports and harbors that require heavy engineering construction services. Most smaller scale contractors only operate on a regional basis. Larger contractors compete for national projects and can form joint ventures to work on larger scale commercial building construction.

regulations_points.regulation_description: OSHA sets and enforces standards to ensure safe and healthy working conditions. It requires construction sites to implement effective safety practices, including proper equipment usage, hazard communication, and employee training. Non-compliance can result in hefty fines, making it crucial for companies to stay vigilant and proactive in adhering to these guidelines.

Local, state and national building codes set minimum construction standards to ensure structural safety and quality. These codes cover everything from materials and design to electrical systems and fire safety. Staying updated with the latest codes is vital, as they frequently change to incorporate new technologies and safety insights.

The EPA's regulations focus on reducing the environmental impact of construction activities. Companies must manage pollutants, handle hazardous materials responsibly and mitigate air and water contamination. Compliance involves conducting environmental assessments and securing necessary permits. Failure to comply can lead to significant project delays and financial penalties.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry receives low and steady assistance.
The industry has a high level of technology change.
Contractors must comply with state and local construction codes and OSHA guidelines, posing a challenge for new entrants lacking regulatory experience.
Established companies have advantages like work history, supplier relationships and economies of scale, making it tough for newcomers to compete.
The complexity of construction projects is a significant barrier as newcomers struggle to establish credibility compared to large players.

factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has a low capital intensity level.
The industry has a low concentration level.
The industry has a low to increasing globalization level.

basis_points.basis_description: Large companies with adequate resources often secure government contracts and grants, sidelining smaller competitors.
Large engineering firms typically hire subcontractors to support regional and varied project needs, maintaining efficiency and broadening reach.
For private construction projects, large companies are selected from a preferred list based on reputation tied to quality of work.
Large companies expand market share by establishing presence across geographic markets, often through acquisitions.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is highly fragmented with many small companies employing only 5 individuals, focused on repairs and maintenance.
Larger operators secure the majority of large construction projects more efficiently by leveraging their size and hiring subcontractors.
Most financing comes from public bodies, requiring large companies to meet stringent regulations to secure this business.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Commodity Price Hikes Cut Into Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2020 and 2021, input prices surged due to supply chain constraints and operating conditions remaining rocky. This dynamic was further exacerbated as oil costs, an essential industry input, skyrocketed due to the recent and ongoing Russia-Ukraine war. As prices have since fallen, profit has begun to recover.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: SUBCONTRACTING PROVIDES A REPRIEVE FROM HIGH PURCHASE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs increases have been tempered by increased subcontracting. On medium- to large-scale projects, the prime contractor takes responsibility for the supply of material purchases (e.g. steel, refractory and concrete components). Large enterprises focus on developing the engineering and design stages before subcontracting works out.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital costs are relatively low, allowing new entrants to compete for smaller local contracts. Established companies can leverage their financial advantages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: REVENUE PERFORMS ACCORDING TO THE EBB AND FLOW OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE INVESTMENT
volatility_points.volatility_description: While overall government spending remained tepid during much of the current period, mass transit projects at the federal, state and local levels experienced tremendous growth. The pandemic significantly heightened industry revenue volatility, as the value of private nonresidential construction was depleted in 2020.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Shifts in Commodity Prices Dictate Pace of Revenue Growth
volatility_points.volatility_description: Commodity prices, such as oil and steel, behaving capriciously for the majority of the period caused swings in railroad- and commodity-related investment structures, which increased industry revenue volatility. Industry profitability has been especially hindered by inflation in commodity prices, with purchase costs expanding in unison with rising wages.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: BIM INTEGRATION CRUCIAL TO PROJECT MANAGEMENT
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Building Information Modelling (BIM) collates information for managing rail assets after construction. Adoption of BIM is more common for large-scale projects and can help contractors strip significant waste from their processes.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: INNOVATIVE MONITORING TECHNOLOGY ENABLES EFFICIENT MAINTENANCE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Remote condition monitoring rail assets' performance has allowed contractors to rely on condition-based maintenance instead of time-based maintenance. Using unmanned vehicles, such as drones and robots, has facilitated this without the need for significant additional labour.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage price risk in regard to demand for differing product segments?
FAQs.answer: Demand for specific types of construction will fluctuate depending on demand conditions. As demand fluctuates, output prices will also fluctuate. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, demand for nonresidential construction has fallen sharply amid a decline in capital expenditure from downstream customers. Furthermore, competition for public dollars amid rising federal spending and weakness in state and local tax revenue has caused demand for industry services to decline.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage interest rate risk?
FAQs.answer: Yields on the 10-year Treasury and other long-term bonds will affect investment mix as they rise due to rising interest rates on 30-year commercial mortgages. As borrowing costs rise, funding of major projects may become scarce and industry operators may need to scale down operations. Locking in low-interest rates via a fixed-rate contract can protect industry operators from potential increases in interest rates and keep the cost of debt from rising, freeing cash flow for current operations.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage market risk?
FAQs.answer: As a result of the coronavirus pandemic, end-market activity has been highly volatile. Due to a downturn in private demand for industry construction and amid a tightening in public dollars as local and state governments increase unemployment liabilities. To hedge against market risk it is imperative that industry operators enter into long-term service contracts for maintenance, ensuring steady revenue flows during periods of market-downturn.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage input-price risk?
FAQs.answer: Building materials such as cement and lumber have been in high demand during the coronavirus pandemic. Rising prices due to limited supplies has caused some industry operators to reflect declines in profitability due to rising operating costs. To protect themselves from rising costs, industry operators should enter into long-term purchasing contracts with upstream suppliers and lock in rates, obtaining upside protection.

FAQs.question: Has your company employed drone technology on job sites?
FAQs.answer: With the Federal Aviation Administration's recent ruling on commercial drone usage, it is now legal to use commercial drones under a certain height limit without licensure. This opens up many avenues for industry operators to employ this labor-saving technology to scope out job sites, 3D map buildings and heat map constructions. Overall, the increased operational efficiency and the resultant decline in wage costs is likely to boost operator operating profit as a result.

FAQs.question: Has your company increased returns on capital?
FAQs.answer: This industry is primarily labor-intensive, and the most efficient method of reducing labor costs is via the subcontracting of nonessential employees. However, it is also possible to reduce reliance on labor by increasing capital intensity and adopting a more capital-intensive operating model. By leveraging gains in technology and capital, industry operators can increase operating profit via a reduction in labor costs and increase in return on capital employed such as heavy machinery or drones.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the construction site?
FAQs.answer: With the current administration walking back deregulations enacted by its predecessor, it is likely that operating costs related to worker health and safety may rise in the short-term. As a result, profitability may be weakened. However, companies that have a penchant for strong safety standards, and a low incidence rate on job sites, will likely be faced with lower insurance premiums and costs, while also setting the standard for the industry, ultimately enhancing operating profit.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: With the current administration's rejoining of the Paris Climate Accord, operating costs related to carbon emissions as well as procurement of similar supplies may rise. This increase in regulation will be most felt by companies that do not exhibit a strong reputation for environmentally friendly construction methods. Those with a penchant for sustainable building will likely be favored by the market while also being less inhibited by rising regulation.

FAQs.question: In a market with essentially substitutable products, how does your company differentiate itself from its major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies can best distinguish themselves from their competition via a reputation for on-time deliverables, under-budget projects, and quality construction. Overall, since industry products are mostly substitutable, a contract tender may be won by offering quality service and via a strong word-of-mouth reputation. Overall, industry marketing costs are minimal.

FAQs.question: Has your company faced any cashflow issues amid the dearth of construction projects at the height of the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Overall, revenue from projects is recognized once a project is completed, creating a lag between work done and revenue gains. As a result, industry operators must have strong cash flow in order to procure supplies, pay workers and finish the project before they can be paid. Essentially this comes down to the fact that investments in construction are considered risky since the product being paid for does not yet exist. To keep cashflow free, industry operators should take advantage of low-interest rates, debt refinances options, as well as having cash reserves to cover operating costs when work slows down.

FAQs.question: How does your company attract skilled and accredited engineers? Have you had any past issues in accessing a highly skilled workforce?
FAQs.answer: Labor is one of the most expensive components of the industry cost structure since skilled and accredited engineers and other professionals cost a premium. Overall, labor costs can be lowered via the subcontracting of nonessential labor and only keeping skilled employees on the books as full-time.

FAQs.question: Do you have a good relationship with your subcontractors? How do you decide which subcontractors to do business with?
FAQs.answer: Having good working relationships with subcontracting building trade specialists is important. Subcontractors are one of the easiest ways to control costs on a construction project. The prime contractor will win the tender for a contract and then may enlist subcontractors in order to perform construction work, while full-time employees will design and engineering industry projects.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to increase productivity via the adoption of technology? What new technology have you recently adopted?
FAQs.answer: Via the adoption of technology, industry operators can increase productivity which will in turn increase industry profitability. Technology is rapidly advancing and must be continuously leveraged in order to remain competitive.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the value of the 10-year Treasury note? What deals can you secure now before interest rates increase further?
FAQs.answer: The yield is analogous to the current interest rate demanded by the market to hold this debt for 10 years. A higher yield translates to higher borrowing costs for the public sector and dissuades industry investment.

FAQs.question: Is your company overly dependent on public dollars to finance projects? Do you have plans to change the level of public financing your company receives?
FAQs.answer: Since a large portion of industry activity is undertaken by state and local governments, increases in their investment outlays will benefit industry growth.

FAQs.question: Do you track investments the government makes in your industry? How have fluctuations in government investments affected your company?
FAQs.answer: Outlays for transportation are used to service interstate transportation, such as navigable waterways, interstate passenger rail and highways. When industry-relevant projects receive federal funding, industry revenue rises.
